Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: Trash pickup is tomorrow and the bins are only half-full with plenty of room left.
Expectation2: Represent clients in court hearings and trials
Situation2: A multi-day jury trial with significant damages at stake is set to commence shortly and cannot be delayed.
Story: I stood in my driveway, staring at the half-full trash bins. My neighbor, Mrs. Patel, had just asked if I could wait until her family finished their spring cleaning tonight before rolling the bins to the curb. She hoped to avoid cluttering the sidewalk with extra bags. As her neighbor, I wanted to be considerate—she’d always been thoughtful about our shared fence and even watered my plants when I was away. But my mind kept drifting to the courthouse. Tomorrow, I’d be in the thick of a high-stakes jury trial, representing a client whose future depended on my focus and preparation. There would be no time to rush home and deal with trash in the morning, and missing the pickup would mean overflowing bins for another week. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in—my neighbor’s trust and my client’s reliance. My hands tightened on the bin handle, torn between being the good neighbor and the diligent lawyer, knowing I couldn’t fully satisfy both.
